title: 110_hr1283
content: The Act titled "Arthritis Prevention, Control, and Cure Act of 2008" enhances public health activities related to arthritis through the National Arthritis Action Plan. It amends the Public Health Service Act to implement the National Arthritis Action Program. The Secretary may establish a National Arthritis Action Program to control, prevent, and surveil arthritis and other rheumatic diseases through research, training, and technical assistance. The Secretary may provide support for arthritis prevention research at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to encourage expansion of related research. Eligible entities include national public or private nonprofit entities demonstrating satisfaction criteria. Under the Program, the Secretary may coordinate national education and outreach activities to support arthritis and other rheumatic diseases through initiatives like public awareness campaigns and community workshops. The Secretary may prioritize prevention, early diagnosis, and management of arthritis, focusing on high-risk or underserved populations. Collaboration with stakeholders from various sectors is required. Eligible entities include national public or private organizations. The term 'eligible entity' refers to a national public or private nonprofit organization that can demonstrate the ability to carry out specified activities. The Secretary may award grants to eligible State or Indian tribe entities for comprehensive arthritis control and prevention programs. To be eligible for a grant under this subsection, an entity must submit an application to the Secretary with a comprehensive arthritis control and prevention plan developed with input from stakeholders. The plan aims to reduce arthritis morbidity, prioritize at-risk populations, and address disparities in prevention and diagnosis. The entity applying for a grant must submit a comprehensive arthritis control and prevention plan to address disparities in arthritis prevention, diagnosis, management, and quality of care in underserved populations. The plan should describe arthritis-related services, demonstrate the relationship with the community, and involve local entities in carrying out activities. Eligible entities can use grant funds to conduct activities aligned with the submitted plan. The entity applying for a grant must submit an application outlining public health surveillance, education programs, and training activities for health professionals to address arthritis disparities. The application must meet the Secretary's requirements and detail how the grant funds will support the entity's efforts. Under a grant awarded under this section, funds will supplement or fulfill unmet needs in a comprehensive arthritis control and prevention plan. Definitions for "Indian tribe" and "State" are provided. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2009-2012 is specified. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 is set at $38,000,000 and $40,000,000 respectively. The Department of Health and Human Services, in coordination with the National Institutes of Health, may expand programs for research on juvenile arthritis and related conditions. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will conduct public health and surveillance activities related to juvenile arthritis. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section on surveillance and research regarding juvenile arthritis. The Secretary may award grants and agreements for data collection on juvenile arthritis. Technical assistance can be provided instead of cash. Information collected must be shared with the National Institutes of Health. A national database on juvenile arthritis will be created in collaboration with a health organization. A voluntary health organization with experience in juvenile arthritis may support the development of a national database to collect data for follow-up studies on the prevalence and incidence of juvenile arthritis. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 for this purpose. Investment in training future pediatric rheumatologists is authorized with $25,000,000 allocated for fiscal years 2009 through 2013. To ensure an adequate supply of pediatric rheumatologists, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will support increased training grants and public-private partnerships. $3,750,000 is authorized for this purpose. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a pediatric rheumatology loan repayment program with a budget of $3,750,000 for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013. Qualified health professionals, specifically pediatric rheumatologists, will be contracted to provide healthcare in underserved areas. The pediatric rheumatology loan repayment program established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services offers up to $25,000 annually to support pediatric rheumatologists. Additionally, professionals may receive reimbursement for tax liability equal to 39 percent of the total repayment amount. The pediatric rheumatology loan repayment program offers up to $25,000 annually to support pediatric rheumatologists. The program assesses the shortage of pediatric rheumatologists in specific areas based on the ratio of children in need to available rheumatologists within 100 miles. The Secretary of Health and Human Services periodically evaluates the program's effectiveness in increasing the number of pediatric rheumatologists. The Secretary periodically assesses the pediatric rheumatology loan repayment program's effectiveness in increasing the number of pediatric rheumatologists nationally and in areas with shortages. If the Secretary determines no longer a need for the program, it will be terminated. Annual reports on the assessments are submitted to Congress. Funding is provided by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for the program's implementation. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may reserve appropriate amounts from the Health Resources and Services Administration's budget for the fiscal year. Amounts allocated for this section remain available until the end of the second year. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 27, 2008. Clerk: LORRAINE C. MILLER.
